questions.text: Which type of joint is the talocalcaneonavicular joint?
questions.solution:
Talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket type of synovial joint. 

 It resembles a ball and socket joint in several ways. The head of talus is inserted into a socket that is partially formed by the navicular bone and partially by the calcaneum. The medial limb of the bifurcate ligament laterally and the spring ligament medially both contribute to the formation of the socket.

Other options: -

  • Ellipsoid joint - metacarpophalangeal joint, metatarsophalangeal joint.
  • Hinge joint- Elbow, ankle joint.
  • Saddle joint- sternoclavicular joint, calcaneocuboid joint.
 

Reference : BD CHAURASIA , VOL-2 ,7th Edition ,Pg-152

questions.text: Which of the following sinuses grows until early adulthood?
questions.solution:
The frontal sinuses are rudimentary at birth, usually well developed between the seventh and eighth years of life, although they don't fully mature until after puberty.

Maxillary and ethmoid sinus are fully developed at around 12 years.

However, frontal and ethmoid sinuses take 18 and 12 years respectively for completion.

questions.text: What form does the trapezius muscle have?
questions.solution:
Trapezius is a triangular muscle.

The flat, triangular muscle known as the trapezius protects the back of the neck and shoulder. When the two trapezius muscles are combined, they resemble a trapezium or quadrilateral, where the shoulders are represented by two of the angles, the occipital protuberance by the third, and the 12th thoracic vertebra's spine by the fourth.

It is innervated by the 11th cranial nerve along with sternocleidomastoid muscle. 


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 853

questions.text: Which specific muscle aids in the opening of the jaw?
questions.solution:
The muscles marked in the given image are as follows-

a- Masseter- Elevation of jaw and protrusion

b- Medial Pterygoid- Elevation of mandible and protrusion

c- Lateral Pterygoid- Depression of mandible and protrusion of jaw

d- Buccinator- Helps in blowing action

Trick- 

1. All muscles of mastication cause protrusion of jaw except temporalis which causes jaw retraction.

2. All muscles of mastication help in elevation of mandible except lateral pterygoid which depresses the mandible causing mouth opening. 

3. The key to identify lateral pterygoid muscle as shown in the image is to look for its insertion in temporo-mandibular joint.

questions.text: Which of the following has dense irregular connective tissue?
questions.solution:
The dermis of the skin, the walls of large tubular organs like the alimentary canal, in glandular tissue, and organ capsules are all examples of dense irregular connective tissue.

Highly fibrous tissues with regularly oriented fires, such as fasciae and apo- neuroses, or bigger bundles like ligaments or tendons, are considered regular connective tissues.

questions.text: What is the root value of the cremasteric reflex?
questions.solution:
The root value of cremasteric reflex is L1-L2. The femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve (L1,L2) houses the afferent fibers of the cremasteric reflex arc, while its genital branch houses the efferent motor nerve fibers.

In Cremasteric reflex, stroking skin at upper and inner thigh, causes upward movement of testis.

choices.text: Present medial to the white ramus communicans

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about grey communicans?
questions.solution:
The sympathetic ganglia present on either side of the vertebral column are connected to spinal nerves by white and grey rami communicans. The cell bodies of the preganglionic sympathetic nervous system neurons are present in lateral horn of spinal cord. They leave the cord via ventral root to enter spinal nerves. From spinal nerves, they enter the sympathetic ganglia via white rami communicans and synapse with cell bodies of postganglionic sympathetic neurons. The axons of the postganglionic sympathetic neurons re-enter the spinal nerves via grey rami communicans. 

To summarize- 

1. White rami communicans- Preganglionic sympathetic fibers, myelinated ( type B ) and release acetylcholine

2. Grey rami communicans- Postganglionic sympathetic fibers, unmyelinated ( type C ) and release norepinephrine. 

Trick- All neurons which exit the central nervous system- brain and spinal cord such as cranial nerves, preganglionic parasympathetic and sympathetic fibers release acetylcholine. 

Reference- BD CHAURASIA ,VOL-3,7th Edition Pg-160

questions.text: Which of the following layers has a large number of desmosomes?
questions.solution:
The given histopathology image is of skin.
Stratum spinosum or prickle cell layer contains abundant desmosomes marked with the legend 'C' in the image.

Picture shows following layers of epidermis:
A : Stratum corneum
B : Stratum granulosum
C : Stratum spinosum
D : Stratum basale

The stratum spinosum, also known as the prickle cell layer, is made up of several layers of densely packed keratinocytes that interdigitate with one another via a large number of cell surface projections. Desmosomes, which give the layer its tensile strength and cohesiveness, anchor the cells to one another. As additional cells are created in the basal layer, these suprabasal cells, which are dedicated to terminal differentiation, eventually ascend upward towards the cornified layer.

In pemphigus group of disorder antibodies are formed against desmosomes, that lead to destruction of cell to cell adhesion and formation of blisters in skin.



Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 145,146,147,148

A : Incus

The vestibule is positioned anteriorly to the three semicircular canals: anterior (superior), posterior, and lateral (horizontal). Each one is squeezed from side to side until it is about two-thirds of a circle in size.
Except for where they bear an ampulla, which is about twice as wide as the canal, they are unequal in length but similar in diameter along their lengths.

questions.text: How are slow waves produced?
questions.solution:
Slow waves are generated by complex interactions among the smooth muscle cells and specialized cells, called the interstitial cells of Cajal.
insterstitial Cells of Cajal is known as the pacemaker cells of intestines.

These interstitial cells connect to smooth muscle cells in a manner akin to synapses and are situated between the layers of smooth muscle. The unique ion channels in the Cajal interstitial cells periodically open and cause inward (pacemaker) currents, which may result in slow wave activity.

These variations in membrane potential cause the interstitial cells to cycle.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 486

questions.text: Which is the reflex that causes tachycardia when the right atrium is distended?
questions.solution:
Bainbridge reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension.
The Bainbridge Reflex, also known as the atrial reflex, controls heart rate by raising atrial pressure, which can sometimes raise heart rate by up to 75%. A tiny portion of this increase is due to the stretched sinus node as a direct result of the increased atrial volume; this direct stretch can raise heart rate by as much as 15%.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 581

questions.text: Which hormone can you identify from the picture?
questions.solution:
Release of growth hormone is stimulated by strenuous exercise. Also during sleep, large pulsatile bursts of growth hormone secretion occur.

Factors which stimulate secretion of growth hormone:
(1) starvation, especially with severe protein deficiency;
(2) hypoglycemia or low concentration of fatty acids in the blood;
(3) exercise;
(4) excitement;
(5) trauma; and
(6) ghrelin, a hormone secreted by the stomach before meals.

questions.text: Which of the following is regulated using a feed-forward control system?
questions.solution:
Feed forward control system is employed during the regulation of temperature. Our bodies have a control mechanism that nevertheless anticipates and makes adjustments when no stimulus is present. A system like this is known as feed forward, anticipatory control, or adaptive control. Temperature control : The hypothalamus starts the thermoregulatory reactions before the changes in external temperature really cause the body's core temperature to change

questions.text: What causes a difference in the curve's trajectories for the inspiratory and expiratory loops?
questions.solution:
The curves produced during inflation and deflation show differences. Hysteresis is the name given to this variation, which is noticeably absent from the curves produced by saline. Hysteresis is influenced by the alveolar environment, particularly the produced substances that lower surface tension and prevent alveoli from collapsing.

choices.text: Closure of active gates of sodium channel
Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel

questions.text: What causes the absolute refractory period?
questions.solution:
Absolute refractory period is due to closure of inactive gates of sodium channel. Absolute Refractory Period: The Na channels quickly switch from their open state to a closed state known as the inactivated state, where they stay for a brief period of time before returning to their resting state where they can once more be activated. This period starts from the time the firing level is reached until repolarization is about one-third complete.

Na channel has got 2 gates- outer m gate (activation gate) and inner h gate (inactivation gate). After the spike potential and when repolarisation begins the h gates close and never allow further sodium entry, depolarisation- This period in the early repolarisation is called the absolute refractory period. During the late repolarisation m gate start to close while the h gates starts opening, so sufficient stimulus can push sodium inside and cause depolarisation- this phase is known as Relative refractory period. 



Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 88

questions.text: Which from the list given below does not undergo post-translational modification?
questions.solution:
Selenocysteine is not formed as a result of post-translational modification, but rather is directly introduced through co-translation into a developing polypeptide during translation.

Thus, selenocysteine is often referred to as the "21st amino acid."

But unlike the other 20 amino acids, selenocysteine's incorporation is controlled by a substantial and intricate genetic component for the peculiar tRNA that makes use of the STOP-signaling UGA anticodon.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 18.

questions.text: Which vitamin from the list below is necessary for glycogen phosphorylase?
questions.solution:
Pyridoxal phosphate is the cofactor of glycogen phosphorylase, where the phosphate group is catalytically important.

Pyridoxal phosphate is a coenzyme for a variety of enzymes, including those involved in the transamination and decarboxylation of amino acids. It serves as a cofactor for the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase, whose catalytic role is supplied by the phosphate group. Vitamin  B6 is also crucial for the activity of steroid hormones.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 166.

questions.text: A DNA's structure is displayed below. What ties two nitrogenous bases together?
questions.solution:
Nitrogenous bases are held together by hydrogen bonds.

Deoxyguanosine nucleotide and deoxycytidine nucleotide are joined by three hydrogen bonds created by hydrogen linked to electronegative N or O atoms, while the A-T pair is joined by two hydrogen links.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 397.

questions.text: The results of the tests for proteins, sugar, and ketones are listed below. Which of the following will show up as positive in urine when someone is starving?
questions.solution:
Only 3 will be positive in cases of starvation.

Test 1 - Biuret test for proteins
Test 2 - Benedicts test for reducing sugars
Test 3 - Rothera’s test for ketone bodies.

Higher than normal quantities of ketone bodies present in the blood or urine constitutes hyperketonemia or ketonuria, respectively. The overall condition is called ketosis. The basic form of ketosis occurs in starvation. Ketone bodies will be positive in starvation in the patient's urine.


In **diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)**, both urine sugar and ketones are present, while in **starvation ketosis**, urine sugar is absent, but ketones are present.


Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 84.

questions.text: What kind of DNA repair is defective in severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)?

Non-homologous end joining repair is defective in severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID).
Other examples of human disease of DNA damage repair:

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 242.

questions.text: A child exhibits hypotonia and seizures. It was determined to be Zellweger syndrome. In the case of Zellweger syndrome, which of the following builds up in the brain?
questions.solution:
Peroxisomal disorders are a group of rare genetic conditions caused by problems in the formation or function of **peroxisomes**, which are small structures in cells responsible for breaking down fatty acids and other toxic substances.  

### Key Features
1. **Cause**: Genetic mutations affecting peroxisome formation or enzyme function.  
2. **Main Functions Affected**:  
   - Breakdown of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs).  
   - Production of essential lipids like plasmalogens (important for brain and lung function).  
3. **Common Symptoms**:  
   - Developmental delays.  
   - Neurological issues (e.g., seizures, muscle weakness).  
   - Liver problems and vision or hearing loss.  

### Examples of Peroxisomal Disorders:  
- **Zellweger Syndrome**: Severe disorder affecting peroxisome formation, often fatal in infancy.  
- **Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD)**: Accumulation of VLCFAs affecting the brain and adrenal glands.  

Zellweger's (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome is characterized by accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids.

The unusual inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues is known as Zellweger's (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome, and it affects some people. They display a broad loss of peroxisomal activities as well as an accumulation of C, Ca polyenoic acids in the brain tissue. Most victims of the illness pass away during the first year of life due to its severe neurological symptoms.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 225.

questions.text: Which of the following can be determined using a dried blood drop from an infant?
questions.solution:
Dried blood drop of an infant can be used to know inborn errors of metabolism with the help of tandem mass spectrometry.

Blood samples from infants can be screened using tandem mass spectrometry for the presence and quantities of amino acids, fatty acids, and other metabolites. A number of hereditary illnesses, including phenylketonuria, ethylmalonic encephalopathy, and glutaric acidemia type 1, can be diagnosed by abnormalities in metabolite levels.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 645

questions.text: Which of the following blood preservatives can be used for  35-day blood storage period?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) CPDA-1

CPDA-I is a common anticoagulant-preservative and allows storage of BC concentrates for 35 days.

questions.text: Which of the following pathways is activated when calcium and thromboplastin are added to platelet-poor plasma for the purpose of estimating prothrombin time (PT)?
questions.solution:
In Prothrombin time (PT) estimation, addition of calcium and thromboplastin to platelet poor plasma activates extrinsic
pathway.

The prothrombin time (PT) assay evaluates how well the extrinsic pathway's proteins work (factors VII, X, V, II, and fibrinogen). The time it takes for a fibrin clot to form is measured when tissue factor, phospholipids, and calcium are added to the plasma.

Trick to memorize:- 
PT- short word(2 letters) so shorter pathway - extrinsic pathway
aPTT- bigger word(4 letters) so longer pathway- intrinsic pathway


Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 662

questions.text: Investigation of a patient with bilateral proptosis determine the diagnosis using the region's biopsy that has been provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Schwannoma
 
  • The given histopathological slide along with clinical features goes in favor of schwannoma. 
  • Schwannomas often abut orbital apertures, and patients present with nonspecific symptoms such as progressive painless proptosis.
  • On histopathological examination, in the Antoni A pattern of growth, elongated cells with cytoplasmic processes are organized in fascicles in regions of moderate to high cellularity and substantial stromal matrix.
  • The "nuclear-free cones" of processes that lie in between the regions of nuclear palisading are known as Verocay bodies.
  • A loose meshwork of cells, microcysts, and myxoid stroma make up the Antoni B pattern of head and neck tumors, which are less densely cellular.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1237.

questions.text: What will a five-year-old patient with HbA2 3% and HbF 97% have on their peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) 1, 2 and 3
 
  • Presence of 3% of HbA2 and 97% of HbF in a child is highly suggestive of thalassemia major.
  • In thalassemia major, nucleated RBCs with target cells, Howell-Jolly bodies and teardrop cells (Dacrocytes) are seen, which implies 1,2 and 3 as the correct option.
  • Blood smears show severe red cell abnormalities, including marked variation in size (anisocytosis) and shape (poikilocytosis), microcytosis, and hypochromia.
  • Target cells (so called because hemoglobin collects in the center of the cell), basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells also are common.
  • Inclusions of aggregated α chains are efficiently removed by the spleen and not easily seen.
  • The reticulocyte count is elevated but is lower than expected for the severity of anemia because of ineffective erythropoiesis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 645.

questions.text: Which of the following does not contribute to iron metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Transthyretin
 
  • The liver produces transthyretin, a normal serum protein that transports thyroxine and retinol-binding protein. Transthyretin does not participate in iron metabolism.
  • Transthyretin (TTR) is a normal serum protein that binds and transports thyroxine and retinol.
  • Several distinct mutant forms of TTR (and its fragments) form amyloid in a group of genetically determined disorders referred to as familial amyloid polyneuropathies.
  • Unmutated TTR may also deposit as amyloid in the heart of aged individuals (senile systemic amyloidosis).
* Proteins involved in Fe metabolism include:
  • Ceruloplasmin
  • DMT1
  • Ferrireductase
  • Ferritin
  • Ferroprotein
  • Hepcidin
  • Hephaestion
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 260.

questions.text: Which of the following is not reduced in iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) TIBC

Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) is increased in iron deficiency anemia.
In case of iron deficiency anemia since the relative free transferrin concentration is high; it is potentially able to bind to more amounts of iron, hence TIBC increases.

* Trick- Two 'Ts' increase in iron deficiency anemia- TIBC and soluble transferrin receptors. Remaining parameters of iron metabolism decrease. 

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 751.

questions.text: Which of the following scores requires additional FISH research when there is Her-2/neu immunohistochemistry staining in cases of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) 2+

A score of 2+ is required for further FISH study.

About 20% to 25% of breast cancers have an overexpressed HER-2 protein or HER-2 gene. Protein overexpression brought on by amplification is clinically assessed by immunohistochemistry and graded on a scale of 0 to 3+. As an alternative, fluorescent in situ hybridization directly measures the two normal copies of the HER-2 gene.

Her-2neu IHC interprtation-

1+ Negative

2+ Equivocal- FISH is done to confirm the amplification

3+ Positive Her2neu

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 191.

questions.text:
A patient who was depressed and had a history of the rapid onset of dyspnea arrived. An X-ray of the chest reveals bilateral diffuse infiltrates, with the right middle
and lower lobes being more heavily affected. Despite treatment, he was not able to be saved, and an autopsy revealed that his lungs looked grossly normal.
The following was revealed through histopathology: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia
 
  • The given histological slides depict a granuloma with multinucleated giant cells reacting to acellular debris that could be foreign matter that has been inhaled, similar to what is seen in vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia.
  • Depressed patient, history of rapid start of dyspnea, and chest X-ray revealing bilateral diffuse infiltrates with predominance of involvement of the middle and lower lobes suggest the diagnosis of aspiration pneumonia.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 711.

questions.text: Where is the origin of CLL and SLL?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Post germinal center B cell
 
  • Cell of origin for chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) is naive B-cells in inter-follicular zones.
  • The expression of CD5 and CD23 in CL cells is antigen-experienced, indicating that these cells have undergone secondary modifications, possibly signifying cell activation or nonspecific changes brought on by the malignancy.
  • Consequently, the memory B-lymphocyte may be the CLL cell's original cell.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 594.

questions.text: Which investigation will help in the diagnosis of chloroma in a child with bilateral proptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Peripheral smear
 
  • Chloroma is a presentation of AML most commonly AML M2 >M5>M4 , most commonly manifesting as proptosis.
  • As soon as you suspect chloroma, we should do a peripheral blood smear to check for blasts.
  • Peripheral smear must be done for diagnosis of chloroma.
  • If the peripheral smear is inconclusive we can go for a bone marrow study.
  • Despite the fact that biopsies of chloroma lesions may point to the diagnosis, the results may mimic a number of inflammatory or neoplastic disorders.
  • In order to confirm the diagnosis, immunophenotyping, inspection of peripheral blood smears, and bone marrow aspirates are frequently needed.
  • Hb concentration and platelet count are not helpful in determining the diagnosis of chloroma. Since extramedullary blast growth is the source of chloroma, the leucocyte count may not increase in this condition.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 620.

questions.text: A male patient from a hilly area presented with fever and splenomegaly. TLC was 21000, and the differential revealed metamyelocytes and myelocytes (approximately 40%). Hb was 16, lymphocytes were normal. Patient has Thrombocytopenia. What will be the next investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) FISH
 
  • Hemoglobin in normal as per guidelines for adult male. However, the patient has thrombocytopenia and has myeloid bulge (40% myelocytes metamyelocytes).
  • Therefore, the patient has to be investigated for Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia. The most common cause for which is Philadelphia chromosome.
  • CML is distinguished from other myeloproliferative neoplasms by the presence of a chimeric BCR-ABL gene derived from portions of the BCR gene on chromosome 22 and the ABL gene on chromosome 9.
  • BCR-ABL directs the synthesis of a constitutively active BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase, which in CML is usually 210 kDa in size. In more than 90% of cases, BCR-ABL is created by a reciprocal (9;22) (q34; q11) translocation (the so-called Philadelphia chromosome [Ph]).
* Plan of action : -
Acute Leukemia - Bone Marrow Aspiration 
CML - FISH
CLL- Flow cytometry 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 622.

questions.text:
An endoscopic image of an esophageal lesion is shown below.



What is the expected histopathology finding?


1. 



2. 




3. 




4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Barrett's esophagus
 
  • The given endoscopic image is of Barrett's esophagus, the pale region signifies squamous epithelium of esophagus and the reddish region signifies columnar region.
  • The histopathologic image of option 3 shows the squamous to columnar metaplasia seen in Barrett's esophagus.
  • Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires endoscopic evidence of metaplastic columnar mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.
  • Non-goblet columnar cells, such as gastric-type foveolar cells, may also be present, but there is not universal agreement as to whether they are sufficient for the diagnosis
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient complained of severe dyspnea. There was mitral stenosis with LA hypertrophy. Plants on the mitral valve, which was removed.
What does the image of HPE show?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Aschoff nodule

The presented image displays a confined nodule of mixed mononuclear inflammatory cells with accompanying necrosis.
Large active macrophages inside the inflammation exhibit conspicuous nucleoli and chromatin that has been compressed into long, wavy ribbons (caterpillar cells). The results imply the existence of Aschoff's body.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

choices.text: Inability to induce inflammation to remove the organism
Integration of viral DNA with host DNA

questions.text:
Asymptomatic hepatitis B affects 2–3 percent of the general population, but there is an increased risk of progression to hepatocellular carcinoma.
What could be the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Integration of viral DNA with host DNA
 
  • HBV DNA serves as an insertional mutagenesis agent by randomly integrating into the chromosomes of hepatocytes.
  • 90% of HCCs linked to HBV experience integration of HBV DNA into the host genome, which has been proposed as an early occurrence in persistent viral infection.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 326.

choices.text: Glomerular basement membrane is stained with PAS
Glomerular basement membrane acts as filtration barrier
Glomerular basement membrane is involved in charge dependent filtration

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about the glomerular basement membrane?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Type III collagen is present

Type IV collagen (not the type III collagen) is the main component of the basement membrane, together with laminin.

The underlying mesenchymal cells and the overlying epithelium both contribute to the synthesis of the basement membrane, resulting in a lamellar "chicken wire" mesh (although labeled as a membrane, it is quite porous).

Therefore, the two main components are laminin and amorphous non fibrillar type IV collagen.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 900.

questions.text:
A patient needs 180 mg of ceftriaxone. A 2 mL syringe with 10 divisions per mL is at your disposal. Ceftriaxone 500 mg/5 ml is what's in the vial.
How many divisions will you fill in the 2 ml syringe to administer 180 mg of ceftriaxone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 18

18 divisions in the 2ml syringe should be filled to give 180 mg ceftriaxone.
• 5 mL contains 500 mg drug
• So, 1mL will contain 100 mg
• 1.8 mL will contain 180 mg.
• So 1.8 mL of drug solution is required to give 180 mg of drug to the patient. That is to be taken in a 2 mL syringe.
• In 2mLsyringe, 1mL contains 10 divisions.

So 1.8 mL would come up to 18 divisions.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 24.

questions.text: What is the vancomycin's mode of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Cell wall synthesis inhibition
 
  • Vancomycin inhibits cell wall synthesis.
  • Vancomycin and teicoplanin bind with a high affinity to the D-alanyl-D-alanine terminal of cell wall precursor units to prevent sensitive bacteria from synthesizing cell walls.
  • They cannot pierce the gram-negative bacteria's outer membrane due to their huge molecular size.
  • Vancomycin infusion is associated with red man syndrome due to degranulation of mast cells. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 806.

questions.text: Except for ____ atropine is indicated in all of the following poisonings.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Endrin.

Atropine is not indicated in Endrin poisoning as it is a Organochlorine compound.

In cases of Organophosphate and carbamate poisoning, atropine is the medicine of choice. In poisoning cases involving Baygon (which contains carbamates and organophosphorus), Tik-20 (which contains organophosphorus), and Parathion (which contains organophosphate), atropine is the medication of choice, but not endrin (organochlorine). There is no specific antidote for organochlorine poisoning.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 116, 122.

choices.text: Decreased renal perfusion and reduced urine output

questions.text: A septic shock patient was given intravenous norepinephrine. This drug's response is best assessed by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Increase in mean arterial pressure

Norepinephrine is a medication that is commonly used to treat septic shock.
 
  • Septic shock is a condition that occurs when an infection in the body triggers a severe immune response, leading to low blood pressure and reduced blood flow to vital organs.
  • Norepinephrine is a vasopressor medication that works by constricting blood vessels, which increases blood pressure and helps to improve blood flow to vital organs. The response to norepinephrine is best assessed by monitoring the patient's mean arterial pressure (MAP).
  • Mean arterial pressure is the average pressure in a patient's arteries during one cardiac cycle. It is calculated by adding one-third of the difference between the systolic and diastolic blood pressures to the diastolic blood pressure.
  • MAP is an important indicator of tissue perfusion, which is the delivery of oxygen and nutrients to the body's tissues. In septic shock, tissue perfusion is often impaired, and improving MAP with norepinephrine can help to restore perfusion.
  • Monitoring heart rate is not the best way to assess the response to norepinephrine.
  • While norepinephrine can increase heart rate, this is a secondary effect of the medication and may not be a reliable indicator of its efficacy. Decreased renal perfusion and reduced urine output may occur in septic shock, but they are not the best way to assess the response to norepinephrine.
Therefore, the correct Answer is Increase in mean arterial pressure.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 143.

questions.text: A diabetic and hypertensive patient on multiple medications developed septicemia. The creatinine level in the blood is 5.7 mg/dl. Which of the following medications should be discontinued?
questions.solution:
Metformin should be stopped in this case.

Contraindications of Metflormin:
 
  • Serum creatinine >1.5 mg/dL (men) >1.4 mg/dL (women)
  • eGFR < 30 ml/min
  • CHE
  • Radiographic contrast studies
  • Hospitalized patients
  • Acidosis


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3110.

questions.text:
A diabetic woman who was morbidly obese was on failed metformin therapy. She has had pancreatitis and has a family history of bladder cancer.
The patient is unwilling to receive injections. Which of the following options would be best for lowering her glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Orally administered canagliflozin is a Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter 2 Inhibitor and also causes weight loss. 
 
  • Sitagliptin raises the risk of acute pancreatitis
  • use of Pioglitazone is linked to a slight elevated risk of bladder cancer  and
  • Liraglutide is administered subcutaneously by injections

Canagliflozin is the preferred medication for the clinical scenario at hand. It also helps in weight reduction in obese diabetic patients.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3110.

questions.text: Which of the following drug can decrease the size of prostate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Finasteride.
 
  • Finasteride is a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme 5 α-reductase which converts testosterone into the more active DHT responsible for androgen action in many tissues including the prostate gland and hair follicles. It is relatively selective for 5 α-reductase type 2 isoenzyme which predominates in male urogenital tract.
  • Treatment with finasteride results in decreased prostate size and increased peak urinary flow rate in ~50% patients with symptomatic benign hypertrophy of prostate (BHP).
  • Finasteride has also been found effective in male pattern baldness, though hair follicles have primarily type 1 enzyme.

Option 1 and 4: Prazosin and tamsulosin are selective alpha receptor blockers involved with dynamic component of BPH.

Option 2: Sildenafil acts by selectively inhibiting PDE-5 and enhancing NO action in corpus cavernosum. It is the DOC for erectile dysfunction.

* High Yield Concept-
The urinary obstruction caused by BHP has a static component due to increased size of prostate and a dynamic component due to increased tone of bladder neck/prostate smooth muscle.


Two classes of drugs are available:

  •  α1 adrenergic blockers (prazosin like): they decrease tone of prostatic/bladder neck muscles.
  •  5-αreductase inhibitor (finasteride/dutasteride) which arrest growth/reduce size of prostate.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 326.

questions.text: 2 hours after eating at a restaurant, a young male experienced 5 episodes of loose stools. He is afebrile and slightly dehydrated. What is the next course of action?
questions.solution:
The patient in the hypothetical clinical situation is mildly dehydrated and experiencing diarrhea.

Replacement of lost fluid and electrolytes is crucial for all types of diarrhoea. Fluid replacement with ORS is adequate in cases of mild diarrhea. 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 301, 302.

questions.text: A patient complained of pain in the right lower quadrant of his abdomen. He has a history of right kidney stones. He was given an opioid, which is both a partial agonist mu and an antagonist at kappa receptors. What was the most likely medication administered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Buprenorphine
 
  • Buprenorphine is partial agonist at mu and antagonist at kappa
  • Pentazocine is full agonist at kappa and antagonist at mu
* [Extra Edge]: Nature of interaction of opioid ligands with the three major types of opioid receptors




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 510.

choices.text: Ranitidine one night before and then before the trip

questions.text: Next morning, a person has to travel to Shimla. Which of the following medications could help him with motion sickness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Scopolamine

The most effective medication for the prevention and treatment of motion sickness is scopolamine, a muscarinic antagonist administered orally, parenterally, or trans-dermally. Scopolamine is the doc for motion sickness.

Scopolamine transdermal preparation (TRANSDERM SCOP) has been demonstrated to be extremely effective when administered prophylactically to avoid motion sickness especially in vigorous motions.

The drug should be given prophylactically (0.2 mg oral), because administration after symptoms have set in is less effective; action lasts 4–6 hours. A transdermal preparation applied behind the pinna 4 hours before journey has been shown to protect for 3 days.

Option 2, 3 and 4 doesn't show a lot of promise to be used in motion sickness and are considered to be inferior to hyoscine. Ranitidine and omeprazole decrease the acidity of stomach so are of no use. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 132.

questions.text: A patient on antitubercular medication experienced tingling in his lower limb. Which of the following, when substituted, can result in symptom improvement?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Pyridoxine
 
  • Pyridoxine can be given for improvement of symptoms.
  • Pyridoxine can be used as a preventative measure to halt ATT-induced neuropathy. Peripheral neuritis, which most frequently manifests as paresthesia of the hands and feet in patients taking isoniazid 5 mg/kg daily, can develop if pyridoxine is not administered concurrently.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 829.

questions.text: Which of the following is an illustration of a placebo?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Sham surgery
 
  • A placebo is an inert substance or treatment that has no therapeutic effect on the patient's condition but is given for the psychological benefit of the patient, to satisfy the patient's expectation of receiving treatment, or to serve as a control in a clinical trial.
  • Sham surgery is a surgical procedure that omits a phase that is believed to be therapeutically important.
  • Sham operations serve as an essential scientific control in clinical trials of surgical intervention. This is due to the fact that it isolates the treatment's intended effects as opposed to the unintended consequences brought on by anaesthesia, wound healing, pre- and post-operative care, and the patient's feeling of having undergone a routine procedure.
  • Therefore, sham surgery provides a similar function to placebo medications in removing biases like the placebo effect.

Reference: Wolf, Brian R, and Joseph A Buckwalter. “Randomized surgical trials and "sham" surgery: relevance to modern orthopaedics and minimally invasive surgery.” The Iowa orthopaedic journal vol. 26 (2006): 107-11 doi: https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1888585/

questions.text:
In an experimental setting, an unknown drug is being tested. The obtained results are shown in the table. Which new drug is likely to result from these actions?
 
Parameter Placebo treated New Drug treated
Heart rate 72 86
Systolic BP 110 150
Diastolic BP 80 68
Tremors Absent Present
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Beta-1 and beta-2 agonist
 
  • Beta-1 stimulation increases heart rate and systolic blood pressure, because of its receptors present in the heart.
  • Beta-2 stimulation cause vasodilation by it receptors present in the blood vessels and thus decreases diastolic blood pressure and tremors.
  • Hence, the drug appears to be beta-I and beta-2 agonist. Beta 2 causes phosphorylation of calcium channels and results in palpitations (cardiac muscle) and tremors (skeletal muscle).

Reference:  Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 143.

choices.text: No advice is required as most of the drugs are secreted negligibly in the milk
Tell her to feed the baby just before next dose
Tell mother to feed when it is least efficacious

questions.text: Which of the following instructions regarding drug use should be given to a nursing mother?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Tell her to feed the baby just before the next dose.
 
  • Toxic effects on the infant are largely dependent on entry of the drug in milk in pharmacologically significant amounts.
  • In the case of large number of drugs (except those acting on CNS and few others), the concentration in milk is low, and the breastfed infant receives insufficient quantity to produce adverse effects.
  • But to be on the safer side nursing mothers should be encouraged to feed the infant right before the next dose because this is when the plasma concentration of the drug is at its lowest.
Maintain a gap of 2-3 hours between drug intake and breast feeding. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page No 1020.

choices.text: Adrenaline 0.5 ml of 1:1000 solution by intramuscular route

questions.text: What is the preferred method of treatment for anaphylactic shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Adrenaline 0.5 ml of 1:1000 solution by intramuscular route

Treatment of choice for anaphylactic shock is: Adrenaline 0.5 ml of 1:1000 solution by intramuscular route.

In cases of anaphylactic shock, the parenteral administration of 0.3-0.5 mg of epinephrine usually has a quick effect on the symptoms of bronchospasm, mucous membrane congestion, angioedema, and severe hypotension (0.3-0.5mL of a 1:1000 epinephrine solution). Since skin blood flow (and hence systemic medication absorption from subcutaneous injection) is uncertain in hypotensive patients, intramuscular injection may be the preferred mode of delivery.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 97.

questions.text: Which is the preferred medicine for scrub typhus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Doxycycline

Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. The drug of choice for scrub typhus is doxycycline.



Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1182.

questions.text: Which of the following single agent can provide adequate antimicrobial cover to a patient with gonococcal as well as non-gonococcal urethritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Azithromycin 2 gm oral single dose.
 
  • Treatment of choice for a patient with gonococcal as well as non-gonococcal urethritis is Azithromycin 2gm oral single dose.
  • A single 1-g dose of azithromycin has an unacceptable low cure rate (93%) for gonococcal infections and should not be administered by itself while it has a successful treatment for uncomplicated chlamydial infections.
  • A single 2-g dose of azithromycin, especially in the extended-release microsphere formulation, is more tolerable since it is delivered to the lower gastrointestinal tract.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 804.

questions.text: Isosorbide mononitrate is given to a patient suffering from Prinzmetal's angina. In this case, what is the mechanism of action of nitrates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Endothelium independent coronary vasodilation
 
  • Prinzmetal Angina is due to recurrent localized (occasionally diffuse) coronary vasospasm which may be superimposed on arteriosclerotic coronary artery disease. Abnormally reactive and hypertrophied segments in the coronary arteries have been demonstrated.
  • Nitrates work by causing endothelium-independent coronary vasodilation in Prinzmetal's angina
  • Organic nitrates are broken down to produce nitric oxide (NO), which binds to guanylyl cyclase in vascular smooth muscle cells and raises the level of cyclic guanosine monophosphate, which relaxes the smooth muscle.
Option 1, 2 and 3 are useful in antianginal property of Nitric oxide.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 613.

choices.text: They cause bronchodilatation when given with xanthines
They increase the action of aminophylline on adenosine receptors

questions.text:
An abrupt aggravation of bronchial asthma was evident in the patient. The patient's condition did not get any better after inhaling salbutamol.
The condition improved after intravenous corticosteroids and aminophylline were introduced. What is the corticosteroid's mode of action in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) They increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol
 
  • Corticosteroids increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol.
  • The need for corticosteroids to be administered as soon as is practical during an acute asthma attack is further emphazised by the fact that they have a dual effect in acute asthma, with an early facilitator effect on airway beta-2 adrenoreceptor sensitivity and a later effect on airway inflammation.
  • They benefit by inhibiting inflammatory cytokine production and eosinophilic, lymphocytic infiltration of lungs. They also reduce bronchial hyperreactivity, mucosal edema and suppress inflammatory response to AG: AB reaction or to other trigger stimuli.
  • They improve airflow, reduce asthma exacerbations and may influence airway remodeling, retarding disease progression. They also increase airway smooth muscle responsiveness to β2 agonists and reverse refractoriness to these drugs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 250.

questions.text: Which of the following does not belong to the dimorphic fungi group?
questions.solution:
Dimorphic fungi have two growth forms that emerge under various development circumstances, such as a mould and a yeast.

Pneumocystis jirovecii is a fungus closely related to ascomycetes, not a dimorphic fungus.

Dimorphic fungi include:
• Blastomyces dermatitidis
• Coccidioides immitis
• Coccidioides posadasii
• Histoplasma capsulatum

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 593.

choices.text: It cannot be grown in Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA)

questions.text:
A known seropositive patient presented with complaints of severe intractable diarrhea. He received care using the medication trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His stool examination revealed Isospora Belli. 
The fever remained, but the diarrhea stopped. Examination of the bone marrow revealed the following image of an intracellular fungus:
Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this fungus?
questions.solution:
It cannot be grown in Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA) is a wrong statement for this fungus.

An HIV positive patient's presence of intracellular fungus on bone marrow examination (in tissues) is strongly predictive of disseminated histoplasmosis brought on by Histoplasma capsulatum. Specimens are cultivated on rich media, such as SDA (Sabouraud Dextrose Agar) or IMA Inhibitory Mold Agar) at 25–30°C, and on glucose–cysteine blood agar at 37°C.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 610.

questions.text: Identify the following organism from the given image?
questions.solution:
The given shows septate hyphae, with acute angle branching suggestive of Aspergillus.

Aspergillus hyphae are hyaline, narrow, and septate, with branching at 45° (acute angle branching).

So, it is Acute angle branching aspergillus.

Note- Mucor will show broad ribbon like aseptate hyphae with obtuse angle branching. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 613.

questions.text:
A female from Himachal Pradesh who had experienced thorn pricks a year prior presented with verrucous lesions in the skin and the microscopic
results listed below. Identify the agent.
questions.solution:
History of thorn prick and the image showing sclerotic bodies also known as medlar bodies or copper penny bodies; is highly suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.

The methods of conidiation are used to distinguish the chromoblastomycosis agents.

In tissue, they resemble one another and produce muriform or sclerotic bodies, which are spherical brown cells (4–12 um in diameter) that divide by transverse septation. A cluster of four to eight cells could form as a result of delayed separation and septation in several planes.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 605.

questions.text: What can be identified from 1,3-beta-D-glucan?
questions.solution:
1,3-beta-D-glucan is helpful for identification of invasive candidiasis.

Most fungi have 1-3-Beta-D-glucan (BG) as part of their cell walls. The primary exceptions are cryptococci and the Mucorales (Rhizopus, Mucor, and Absidia), which don't emit enough BG to be seen in human serum.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 384.

questions.text: What is the most effective way to diagnose a Clostridium difficile infection?
questions.solution:
PCR for toxin gene detection in stool is very sensitive and specific for diagnosis of clostridium difficile diarrhea. 

Methods of diagnosis of C. difficile include:
Diagnosis is made after detection of one or both toxins by:
Stool cytotoxin assay
  • PCR 
  • ELISA: ELISA that detects toxin A or B in stool
  •  Colonoscopy: Characteristic ulcers, plaques, and pseudomembranes
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 272.

questions.text: Which among the following viral hemorrhagic fevers have occurred in India?
questions.solution:
Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever has been reported in India.

Viral hemorrhagic fevers are zoonotic diseases brought on by viruses that live in arthropod vectors or animal reservoirs.
The Ebola and Marburg virus infections in Africa, as well as yellow fever in Africa and South America, are only a few instances of the diseases that affect the entire world yet are only present where the host species is present.

Geographically, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever is widely distributed. The first confirmed case of CCHF in India was noted in January 2011 in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, during a nosocomial outbreak.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 531.

questions.text: What is used to clean up blood spills in the operating room?
questions.solution:
• Blood spills in OT are cleaned with chloride compounds. (Sodium Hypochlorite)
  • For Major blood spills, high-concentration chlorine-releasing chemicals offer the most practical and efficient cleaning solution.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 145.

questions.text: Which organism can you identify from the image?
questions.solution:
The given illustration shows endoflagellum which is seen in Leptospira among the given options. 

Treponema, borrelia and leptospira are all spirochetes and they contain the typical endoflagellum (axial filament).

The flagella-like organelles in the periplasmic region enclosed by the outer membrane are known as endoflagella (axial filaments). At each end of the creature, the endoflagella start and wind around it, expanding to and overlapping at the middle.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 377.

questions.text: A biofilm-forming bacteria show antibiotic resistance by all of the following mechanisms except?
questions.solution:
Biofilm does not lead to the property of adherence.

Biochemically and visually, biofilm masses are significantly different from the free-living individual cells known as planktonic cells. Affected microbial metabolism, extracellular virulence factors produced, and decreased susceptibility to biocides, antimicrobial agents, and host defence molecules and cells are all effects of biofilm growth.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 77.

questions.text: Identify the following organism from the given image?
questions.solution:
The picture displays colonies of pink bacilli against a blue background with acid-fast staining indicating that the organisms are acid fast.

Corynebacterium and Actinomyces are excluded because they are not acid fast.

Even though nocardia is acid fast, it appears as long, slender thread with branches.
Therefore, based on the aforementioned scenario, the culture is of mycobacterium and shows a large number of bacilli.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 13.

questions.text: Identify the virus using the provided cycle?
questions.solution:
The given lifecycle is of HIV virus. It has ssRNA and undergoes reverse transcription as shown in the image. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 570.

questions.text: A fecal smear revealed the following findings.Determine the organism's identity.
questions.solution:
The organism is Balantidium coli.

In the given illustration, cilia are present all around the trophozoite. Balantidium coli is the only ciliate known to infest humans.

It exists in two morphological forms-

1. Trophozoites- Oval and shape and contain two nuclei. Cilia covers the entire surface of the organism. It has a narrow anterior end and a broader posterior end. 

2. Cysts- Small and round with a micronucleus, a macronucleus and contractile vacuoles. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 107.

questions.text: Identify the organism based on the stool microscopy provided.
questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates quadrinucleated cyst of Giardia lamblia. 

The organism exists in Infective form which is the quadrinucleate cyst and tennis racket shaped trophozoite which is the motile form. 

Both cysts and trophozoites can be found in the feces. These cysts are hardy and resistant to chlorination. Infection occurs by ingestion of cysts in contaminated water food or hands/fomites. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 33.

questions.text: What conditions are diagnosed with urine LAM?
questions.solution:
Urine lipoarabinomannan (LAM) is used for the diagnosis of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

LAM is a 17.5 kD glycolipid found in the outer cell wall of mycobacteria.  LAM  shows renal clearance, is heat stable and can be easily detected in urine.

As a bacterial product, it theoretically has the ability to distinguish between latent infection and active TB due to the former's larger bacterial content.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 17th edition, Page no 1008.

questions.text: Which one of the following malarial parasites exhibits relapse?
questions.solution:
Relapse is seen in Plasmodium vivax and ovale.

A fraction of the intrahepatic forms of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale infections are dormant for anywhere between three weeks and a year before reproducing.

The relapses that are typical of infection with these two species are brought on by these dormant forms, also known as hypnozoites.

Plasmodium falciparum and malaria exhibit recrudescence. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 77.

questions.text:
Nothing constitutes an offense if it is committed by a person who, at the time of commission, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act or that he is doing
something that is either wrong or contrary to the law.
questions.solution:
In the question, a description of McNaughten's rule is given.

+ McNaughten's Rule: An accused person is not legally responsible, if it is clearly proved, that at the time of committing the crime, eh was suffering from such a defect of reason from abnormality of mid, that he did not know the nature and quality of the act he was doing, or that what he was doing was wrong.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 493.

questions.text: What is the order of development of rigor mortis according to Nysten’s rule?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb
 
  • According to Nysten's rule, order of development of rigor mortis is orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb.
  • The muscles of the body, including voluntary and involuntary, are affected in order of emergence of rigor (Nysten's rule).
  • Not all muscles experience it at the same time. It starts in the involuntary muscles, and within an hour, the myocardium becomes hard.
  • It starts in the muscles of the eyelids, neck, and lower jaw, moves up to the muscles of the face, moves down to the muscles of the chest, upper limbs, belly, and lower limbs, and ends up in the muscles of the fingers and toes.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 161.

choices.text: Male doctor can examine her with female attendant
Gynecologist can abort the fetus upon the patient request

questions.text: Which of the following procedures cannot be performed on a 14-year-old rape victim with 22 weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
Gynecologist can not abort the fetus upon the patient request.

Before performing an abortion, the woman's consent is essential. In the case of a woman who is under the age of 18 or mentally sick, parental written agreement is essential. Since the patient in the question is barely 14 years old, termination requires the guardian's agreement. Only up to 20 weeks of pregnancy may be terminated.

Therefore, a gynaecologist cannot perform an abortion at the patient's request.

Note- This Q has been framed according to older MTP guidelines. According to new MTP Act guidelines in case of rape victim, fetus can be aborted at anytime of gestation. 

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 401.

questions.text: What causes Blackfoot’s disease?
questions.solution:

questions.text:
In a burglarized room, a middle-aged woman was discovered laying in a bloody pool. Upon forensic inspection, a 2 cm by 2 cm entry wound was found on the
left temporal region, which had tattooing and blackening all around it. The right temporal area also has an exit wound with beveling. Two gunshot fragments were
discovered inside the brain parenchyma upon closer inspection. Which of the following could be applied to establish the weapon's firing range?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Hair
 
  • Hair can be used to assess the distance of firing.
  • The presence of burning or singeing (due to flame), blacking (due to smoke), and tattooing are needed findings to compute range (due to gun powder).
  • The tattooing that was discovered is up to intermediate level. Hair should be examined for the presence of any singeing or smoke deposits to determine whether the the gun was discharged from close range.
  • same can be done with clothing, but since the harm in this case is to the skull, hair is a preferable choice.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 224.

questions.text:
An autopsy was done on a woman who had been brought dead to the hospital. No distinct indicators were noticed. Only the chin mark depicted below was visible
upon exterior inspection; nevertheless, during inside inspection, the following appearance was discovered: What's the most likely cause of her death?
questions.solution:
The case appears to be of Throttling.

External inspection reveals a single abrasion, most likely the result of the attacker's fingers grabbing the neck. Additionally, neck bruising was observed. Internal examination reveals injured neck tissues with haemorrhage from the strap muscles. All of these characteristics imply throttling. In the absence of a ligature mark, hanging can be ruled out. Strangulation by ligature cannot exist if there is no ligature mark.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 353.

questions.text: What would be the anticipated number of ANC registrations in a subcenter area with a crude birth rate of 20?
questions.solution:
In a subcenter area with a crude birth rate of 20 ,
the expected number of ANC registrations should be approximately 55, so, the best option stands to be 60.

Number of Expected Pregnancies per Year

• Expected no. of live births
(Y)/year = 20 x 5000/1000 = 100

• Total number of Expected Pregnancies
Z= Y+ 10% of Y= 100 +10% of 100 =110

• Expected number of ANC registrations will be half of yearly calculation = 55

questions.text:
15225 hypertensive individuals were randomly assigned to the intervention group (new medicine) and the control group (old drug) in a clinical trial.
The table below lists the research study's findings. Determine the relative risk (RR) and absolute risk reduction (ARR)?
 
Control group
(old group)		 Intervention
group (new drug)
Developed HT complication 1800 1620
Did not develop HT complications 13425 13605
Total subjects 15225 15225
questions.solution:
In the given situation, absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 1% and relative risk (RR) is 0.9.

Calculation:

• IC = Incidence of events (hypertensive complications) in the control group = 1800/15225 =0.118 =11.8%

• TI = Incidence of events (hypertensive complications) in the treatment group = 1620/15225 = 0.106 =10.6 %

• Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is also known as risk difference.

• ARR = IC-IT =11.8-10.6 = 1.2%

Relative risk (RR) = IT/IC = 0.106/0.118 = 0.9

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 86.

questions.text:
In a statistical analysis to determine how a medicine might affect a patient's blood sugar level, the test indicated a significant difference even though there wasn't one.
What are the most likely causes?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the likely null hypothesis will be that both the drugs are essentially same. This is also true in reality. 

The alternate hypothesis will be that these 2 drugs have significant difference between them. 

The above question states that there is significant difference between these 2 drugs ( p < 0.05 ), so the null hypothesis is rejected. But we are aware of the fact that in reality the null hypothesis is correct.  This is a type 1 or alpha error. 

Definition- When an alterative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and null hypothesis is true, it constitutes a type 1 or alpha error.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 24, 25.

questions.text: A patient arrives with a history of palpitations that started suddenly. The ECG displayed a narrow complex tachycardia with a rate of 160 BPM but no "P" waves. His BP is 96/68 mm Hg. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Carotid sinus massage must be done as the next step
 
  • Clinically, the rapid nature of the palpitations and narrow complex tachycardia without obvious P Waves points to the possibility of atrioventricular re-entrant tachycardia (AVRT), the most prevalent type of SVT.
 
  • Patient is clinically stable with a systolic BP > 90 mm of Hg. Therefore, cardioversion or defibrillation are not required.
 
  • The best next step in management will be a carotid sinus massage (or any other vagal maneuver), as these can stop roughly 10–20% of AVNRTs.
  • Adenosine is still preferred over beta-blockers as a treatment for failed vagal maneuvers in patients with hemodynamic stability.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1893, 1899.

questions.text: Which is the most sensitive indicator of renal tubular function?
questions.solution:
Specific gravity of urine is the most sensitive marker of renal tubular function.

The ability of the kidneys to concentrate, specifically renal tubular function, is measured by urinary specific gravity. Better indices of general renal health and GFR are the serum creatinine levels and clearance.

The best indicator of glomerular function is the GFR.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2305, 2357.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man with a recent history of CVA is hospitalized. He is drowsy and not responding to commands. The CT image is displayed as in the figure.
What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has low GCS  and NCCT of the head shows a large wedge shaped infarct in left MCA territory with significant midline shift. In such a scenario,  decompressive neurosurgery will be the next best step of management in order to prevent impending brain herniation. 
 
  • Decompressive craniectomy is a neurosurgical procedure that reduces increased intracranial pressure in the presence of space-occupying brain lesions or brain swelling due to stroke.
  • Cerebral edema is a potential complication in 5-10% of patients with strokes, leading to obtundation and brain herniation. The severity of edema is highest on the second or third day after the stroke and can last for around 10 days.
  • Medical management may not be successful in case of significant edema or infarcts involving the cerebellum.

 
  • Decompressive surgery is recommended for patients who are less than 60 years old and experience deterioration within 48 hours, despite receiving medical therapy.
  • Hypodensity on head CT within the first 6 hours of stroke onset, involving > one-third of the MCA territory, early midline shift, and a diffusion-weighted imaging volume on MRI within 6 hours >80 mL are predictors of severe cerebral edema. 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3337.

questions.text: A patient with a headache visits the emergency room and claims it is the worst headache he has ever had. What is the next course of treatment?
questions.solution:
“The worst headache I've ever had” is a  symptom of a subarachnoid haemorrhage.

CT of the brain should be the next step for diagnosis.
 
  • The hallmark of aneurysmal rupture is blood in the CSF. More than 95% of cases have enough blood to be visualized on a high-quality noncontrast CT scan obtained within 72 h.
 
  • The extent and location of subarachnoid blood on a noncontrast CT scan help locate the underlying aneurysm, identify the cause of any neurologic deficit, and predict the occurrence of vasospasm.
 
  • If the scan fails to establish the diagnosis of SAH and no mass lesion or obstructive hydrocephalus is found, a lumbar puncture should be performed to establish the presence of subarachnoid blood. Lysis of the red blood cells and subsequent conversion of hemoglobin to bilirubin stains the spinal fluid yellow within 6–12 h. This xanthochromic spinal fluid peaks in intensity at 48 h and lasts for 1–4 weeks, depending on the amount of subarachnoid blood.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354, 3355.

questions.text: Loud S1 in mitral stenosis is absent in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Loud S1 is present in Mild MS.
 
  • In the initial stages of the condition, the first heart sound (S1) is frequently accentuated.
  • Loud S1 in MS is independent of MS severity.
  • The anterior mitral valve leaflet's distance to return to its annular plane, leaflet mobility, left ventricular contractility, and the PR interval all affect S1 intensity.

Causes of loud S1 include:
  • Tachycardia
  • Increased AV flow
  • Prolonged AV flow
  • Short PR interval

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1991, 1992.

questions.text: An intern saw a hypertensive patient's blood pressure readings in the right arm to be 180/100 mm Hg and the left arm to be 130/90 mm Hg during a regular follow-up. He also has an early diastolic murmur in right 2nd intercostal space. Which of the following conditions has the least chance of being connected to these findings?
questions.solution:
Coarctation of aorta, Takayasu arteritis and aortic dissection can cause mid-diastolic murmur but aortic stenosis causes systolic murmur.

Causes of EDM
 
Aortic Regurgitation Backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole due to an incompetent aortic valve. High-pitched decrescendo murmur best heard at the left sternal border. Associated with bounding pulses and wide pulse pressure.
Pulmonic Regurgitation Backflow of blood from the pulmonary artery into the right ventricle due to pulmonary valve insufficiency. Low-pitched decrescendo murmur best heard at the upper left sternal border.
Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) Left-to-right shunt increases flow across the mitral valve, creating a diastolic murmur. Increased flow due to the shunt leads to turbulent flow during diastole.
Tricuspid Regurgitation Backflow of blood from the right ventricle to the right atrium during diastole due to a faulty tricuspid valve. Early diastolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border, accentuated with inspiration.
Aortic Root Dilatation Dilatation of the aortic root causes aortic regurgitation, leading to backflow of blood into the left ventricle. Murmur caused by regurgitant flow through the aortic valve.
Pulmonary Hypertension Increased pressure in the pulmonary artery causes pulmonic regurgitation. Diastolic murmur due to increased backflow through the pulmonic valve.
 
Causes of Unequal BP- 
Coarctation of aorta
Takayasu arteritis
 Aortic dissection



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1981.

questions.text: In which of the following situations is a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis not seen?
questions.solution:
Salicylate poisoning leads to high anion-gap metabolic acidosis.
 
  • Proximal renal tubular acidosis (RIA), pancreatitis and diarrhea lead to normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.
 
  • Salicylates have a direct effect on the respiratory center in the brain leading to hyperventilation.
 
  • The body responds to hyperventilation by having the kidneys produce more bicarbonate and excrete more potassium which leads to an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 361, 364.

questions.text: A patient with fever and a headache arrives at the emergency room. On examination, he has stiffness in his neck. A CSF analysis was performed The opening pressure was increased, proteins were mild, glucose was normal, and lymphocytes were increased. What is the most likely organism responsible for this?

  • Elevated opening pressure, slightly increased proteins, normal glucose, and increased lymphocytes in the CSF assay results are strongly suggestive of viral (Coxsackie virus) meningitis.
Meningitis accompanied by normal glucose levels strongly suggests viral meningitis.

questions.text: A patient arrived with ascites. Ascitic fluid analysis was done and found to have a SAAG greater than 1.1. Which of the following is not a cause?
questions.solution:
In tubercular peritonitis, Serum-Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG) is <1.1gm/dL.
 
  • The SAAG is effective for separating ascites resulting from portal hypertension from ascites without portal hypertension.
  • The SAAG corresponds with the hepatic venous pressure gradient and represents the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids.
  • The SAAG is determined by deducting the serum albumin level from the ascitic albumin concentration, and it is unaffected by diuresis.
  • A SAAG <1. g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension, as in tuberculous peritonitis, peritoneal carcinomatosis, or pancreatic ascites.
 
SAAG \(\geq\) 1.1 g/dl SAAG < 1.1 g/dl

• Fulminant hepatic failure • Peritoneal carcinomatosis
• Liver metastases • Nephropathy
• Budd-Chiari syndrome • Malnutrition
• Portal Vein Thrombosis • Protein-losing enteropathy
• Veno-occlusive Disease • Tuberculous peritonitis

• Pulmonary Hypertension

choices.text: 9L arrived at the blood bank for platelet apheresis for the first time. He had circumoral numbness and paresthesias during

questions.text:
A young donor with a platelet count of 1.9L arrived at the blood bank for platelet apheresis for the first time. He had circumoral numbness and paresthesias during
the course of the donation. But his vital signs are still steady. Tachycardia with ST-T alterations was seen on the ECG. What is the cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Clinical signs of paresthesias, circumoral numbness, and an ECG with tachycardia and ST-T alterations are strongly suggestive of Hypocalcemia brought on by a protracted citrated blood transfusion.
 
  • Citrate chelates calcium and suppresses the coagulation cascade, which is why it is frequently used to anticoagulate blood components.
 
  • Multiple quick transfusions can cause hypocalcemia, which shows up as circumoral numbness and/or tingling in the fingers and toes.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 358.

questions.text: A patient has hypotonia and unilateral ptosis in the same eye. After receiving an IV shot, his symptoms vanished for a breif duration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical findings of unilateral ptosis and hypotonia in the eye with improvement after an IV injection (most probably
edrophonium) indicates Myasthenia gravis.

Clinical features of Myasthenia Gravis:

Muscle weakness and fatiguability are its defining characteristics.

• Weakness may worsen late in the day or after prolonged use (fatigue), although it may also become better after rest or sleep.
• There is a recognizable pattern to how muscular weakness is distributed.

Early on in the course of MG, the cranial muscles (lids and extraocular muscles) are frequently affected.
Ptosis and diplopia are frequent early complaints.

• The patient's attempt to grin is met with a "snarling" face due to facial weakness.
• Chewing weakness is most obvious after exerting a lot of effort, like when chewing meat.

Speech timbre: nasal (due to weakness of palate) Dissonant "mushy" quality (due ot tongue weakness)
• Difficulty swallowing due to pharyngeal, tongue, or palate paralysis, resulting in aspiration or nasal regurgitation.

The edrophonium (Tensilon) test is sometimes of value in distinguishing botulism (usually a negative result) from myasthenia gravis (usually a positive result), which was performed in the question.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1275.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3510, 3511.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in the emergency management of acute hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
• Intravenous magnesium sulfate is not used in the emergency management of acute hyperkalemia.
  • Intravenous calcium stabilizes the myocardium.  Without affecting the resting membrane potential, calcium increases the action potential threshold and decreases excitability. Calcium restores the depolarization blockage caused by hyperkalemia by restoring the difference between resting and threshold potentials.
  • Salbutamol(Beta 2 agonist) as well as insulin cause intracellular shift of potassium, thus decreasing its plasma levels. 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 355.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best clinical guide for the management of resuscitation from shock?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Urine output
 
  • Best guide for the management of resuscitation is urine output.
  • It is assumed that patients who respond well to fluid infusion (normalisation of vital signs, clearing of the sensorium, and warm fingers and toes with normal capillary refill) also have acceptable general perfusion. A quantitative, accurate sign of organ fusion is urine output.
  • In an adult, a child, and a newborn under 1 year old, an adequate urine output is 0.5 mL/kg per hour, 1 mL/kg per hour, and 2 mL/kg per hour, respectively.
  • CVP (central venous pressure), is a measure of the pressure in the large veins near the heart. While it can be a useful indicator of fluid status in patients, it is not always a reliable guide for resuscitation management.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 18, 19, 671.

questions.text: What is the modified shock index formula?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Heart rate/Mean arterial pressure

Modified shock index (MSI) is defined as heart rate divided by mean arterial pressure.
  • Low systemic vascular resistance and a high MSI are indicators of hypodynamic circulation and a high stroke volume value, respectively. Low MSI, on the other hand, denotes a hyperdynamic condition. 
  • It is a better marker than Shock index for mortality rate prediction. SI is known as a hemodynamic stability indicator.
  • Whereas SI and MSI are statistically more accurate than one individual parameter, there is no substitute for the experienced clinician at the bedside. This may be the reason that SI and MSI have not been widely adopted.
* [Extra Edge]: Modified shock index
 
  • MSI is a more important clinical predictor than blood pressure and heart rate because MSI > 1.3 indicates a hypodynamic state.
  • Conversely, low MSI is also a predictor of increased mortality. This is commonly seen in patients with cerebrovascular diseases, chest pain and palpitations.
  • These patients often have increased ICP and arrhythmias, which can be easily identified.
 

SI = HR/SBP

MSI = HR/MAP

MAP = [(DBP × 2) + SBP]/3

(Where; HR = Heart rate; SBP = Systolic Blood pressure; DBP = Diastolic blood pressure; MAP = Mean arterial pressure)

the threshold values as HR at 120 beats per minute, SBP at less than 90 mmHg and SI at cut off 0.5-0.9 and MSI at less than 0.7 to more than 1.3. 

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 51.

questions.text: What is the color of 22 Gauge IV cannula?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Blue

The 22 Gauge IV cannula is blue in color. 
The higher the gauge number, the smaller the cannula.
Different sized cannulas move liquid through them at different rates, known as flow rates.



* [Extra Edge]: 
 

IV cannulas present minor risks to a person. Some potential risk include:

  • mild pain at the insertion site
  • blood clot formation
  • infection at the insertion site
  • bleeding
  • bruising
