questions.text: Which of the following steps is not taken for the transport of a traumatized and conscious patient?
questions.solution:
• The trauma team must constantly take precautions to safeguard the patient from iatrogenic or self-inflicted spinal cord injury.
  • Therefore the patient must not be put in a lateral lying down position.
  • Therefore, until it is established that the patient's vertebral column is intact, either through physical examination, clinical observations, or, when necessary, radiologic confirmation, full spine precautions must be enforced.
  • A rigid cervical collar fitted to the patient stabilizes the cervical spine. The thoracic, lumbar, and sacral parts of the spine are protected by keeping the patient lying supine at all times.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: According to the triage system used in disaster management, which of the following color codes and explanations matches correctly?
questions.solution:
A quick classification of the injured based on the seriousness of their conditions and their chances of survival is called triage.
The second priority color is yellow, and if the patient is stable, observation is needed.

Triage classification:
 
  • Red color : First priority and signifies a critical patient
  • Yellow color : Urgent, second priority

questions.text: What does the reference to French in Foley's catheter mean?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option 3 - Outer Diameter of catheter

#controversial


French or Fr scale is a scale that is used to determine the outer diameter of a catheter, not its circumference as commonly assumed.
1 Fr = 0.33mm in diameter
Outer diameter of a catheter = French(Fr) size/3 in mm
For eg, 6Fr Catheter - will have 6/3 = 2mm outer diameter. 

Note: It is a common misconception that it denotes outer circumference. For those who cleared NEET UG and did even elementary physics/maths and passed - will know that circumference of a circle is pi X diameter
Value of pi is 3.141 - not 3. So, a 6Fr catheter - will have a diameter of 6/3 = 2mm. But circumference would be pi X d(i.e 3.14 X 2mm) = 6.28mm - not 6mm. 
Hopefully, a little recap of Maths would have cleared the doubt - that Fr denotes outer diameter - not Circumference since pi is 3.14, not 3. 


Reference:
1. SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 990.
2. Catheters in vascular interventional radiology: an illustrated reviewhttps://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10679593/
3. NCERT Mathematics Class 7 Circles page 153

questions.text: What is balanced resuscitation in trauma management?
questions.solution:
Balanced resuscitation in trauma management is maintaining permissible hypotension to avoid bleeding.

The present method of treating the exsanguinating patient entails the early application of damage control resuscitation due to the recognized early coagulopathy of traumas (DCR).

Although higher blood and platelet ratios have received the majority of the attention in hemorrhagic shock resuscitation, DCR actually consists of three fundamental elements: permissive hypotension, minimizing crystalloid-based resuscitation, and the immediate release and administration of pre-defined blood products.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old patient was admitted and reported having dyspnea. He had engorged veins throughout his chest and a swollen face upon examination. There may be an SVC blockage. Mediastinal hypertrophy is visible on a chest X-ray. Patient was vitally stable.
What should be the next line of action?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: CT Thorax to confirm the diagnosis
 
  • Extrinsic compression from-
    • Malignancy- Lung carcinoma ( 80 % ) and lymphoma ( 20 % )
    • Fibrosing mediastinitis 
    • Aneurysm
    • Non-malignant mediastinal mass such as lymph node
  • Intrinsic causes- 
    • Intrinsic stenosis 
    • Thrombosis of superior vena cava
Radiographic features-

Plain radiograph- Will demonstrate indirect signs in case of mediastinal mass as underlying etiology such as:
  • Superior mediastinal widening 
  • Right hilar prominence 

CT- Contrast enhanced CT is the imaging modality of choice. It will demonstrate:
  • Location and severity of the superior vena cava obstruction
  • Presence of superimposed thrombosis
  • Mediastinal mass or lymphadenopathy
  • Collateral vessels
  • Associated lung masses

CT scan is the preferred imaging modality for identifying SVC blockage. The most accurate image of mediastinal anatomy is provided by CT. The presence of substantial collateral venous circulation and decreased or absent pacification of central venous structures are necessary for the diagnosis of Superior Vena Cava syndrome.

Clinical signs of SC obstruction include a significant decrease in venous return to the head, neck, and upper extremities.

Lymphoma and metastatic malignancies, as well as small cell and squamous cell carcinoma in the lungs, account for >90% of all cases with SVC syndrome.

Malignant lymphoma is the most common cause of SVC syndrome in young adults.

Treatment includes - Steroids, diuretics, Anticoagulation if there is thrombus formed,  Radiation therapy, Treat underlying malignancy, Bypass surgery in rare cases.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 565, 566.

questions.text: In a superficial partial-thickness burn, which layer is involved in blister formation?
questions.solution:
The American Burn Association (ABA) has published an educational resource that reviewed the classification and management of the burn wound. The classification system below is largely in agreement.
  • Superficial Burns
A superficial (first-degree) burn involves the epidermis only. These burns can be pink-to-red, without blistering, are dry, and can be moderately painful. Superficial burns heal without scarring within 5 to 10 days.
 
  • Partial-Thickness Burns

A second-degree burn, also known as a superficial partial-thickness burn, affects the superficial layer of the dermis (Papillary dermis). Blisters are common and may still be intact when first evaluated. Once the blister is unroofed, the underlying wound bed is homogeneously red or pink and will blanch with pressure. These burns are painful. Healing typically occurs within 2 to 3 weeks with minimal scarring.

A deep partial-thickness burn involves the deeper reticular dermis, can also present with intact blisters. Once the blisters are debrided, the underlying wound bed is mottled and will sluggishly blanch with pressure. The patient with a partial-thickness burn experiences minimal pain, which may only be present with deep pressure. These burns can heal without surgery, but it takes longer, and scarring is unavoidable.
 
  • Full-Thickness Burns

A third-degree burn, also known as a full-thickness burn, is most severe and affects the epidermis and dermis skin layers. They also extend into the subcutaneous tissue. These burns result in a leathery, stiff, and dry appearance. At this depth, the affected area does not blanch under pressure due to compromised blood supply. The nerves at this depth are also damaged, resulting in the patient experiencing no sensation or pain. These burns take more than 8 weeks to heal and require surgical treatment.



Reference- Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition Page no 669

questions.text: When should the next dose of levonorgestrel 0.75 mg be given for adequate protection following unprotected intercourse?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A female patient in the labor ward received an opioid analgesic. Which of the following medications should be kept on hand in case of emergency?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Naloxone
 
  • Naloxone is a medicine that rapidly reverses an opioid overdose. It is an opioid antagonist. This means that it attaches to opioid receptors and reverses and blocks the effects of other opioids.
  • Naloxone can quickly restore normal breathing to a person if their breathing has slowed or stopped because of an opioid overdose.
  • Narcotics used during labor may cause newborn respiratory depression. Naloxone is a narcotic antagonist capable of reversing respiratory depression induced by opioid narcotics. It acts by displacing the narcotic from specific receptors in the central nervous system.
  • After adequate ventilation has been established, naloxone may be given to a newborn whose mother received narcotics.
  • Naloxone is contraindicated in a newborn of a narcotic-addicted mother because withdrawal symptoms may be precipitated (American Academy of Pediatrics, 2017).



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 469, 1150.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman arrived to the infertility clinic's OPD. Bromocriptine was prescribed for her. What could be the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Hyperprolactinemia
Bromocriptine and cabergoline are used in the treatment of Hyperprolactinemia
Bromocriptine is a dopamine D2 receptor agonist used for the treatment of galactorrhea due to hyperprolactinemia and other prolactin-related conditions.
 

Bromocriptine-

  • Starting Dose: Usually begins at 1.25 mg to 2.5 mg daily, taken with food to minimize gastrointestinal side effects.
  • Maintenance Dose: The dose may be gradually increased, typically to a range of 2.5 mg to 15 mg per day, depending on the individual response and the condition being treated.

Cabergoline-

  • Starting Dose: Typically starts at 0.5 mg per week, which can be taken as a single dose or divided into two doses.
  • Maintenance Dose: The dose may be gradually increased, with a common maximum dose of up to 1 mg to 2 mg per week, depending on the patient's response and tolerance.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 150,198, 199.

questions.text: Which of the following deep perineal body structure is injured when cystocele, enterocele, and urethral descent occur?
questions.solution:
Injury to the Pubococcygeus muscle.

The rectum, vagina, and urethra are pulled anteriorly towards the pubic bone as the pubococcygeus muscle contracts, which narrows their lumens.
The genital organs (vagina, cervix, and uterus) that attach to and are maintained by the levator plate depend on this contractile property to maintain urine and faecal continence.
Urinary incontinence, rectocele, and cystocele can all result from injury to the pubococcygeus.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman is diagnosed with primary amenorrhea. She had an immature uterus and a 45XO karyotype upon assessment. What is the next line of action?
questions.solution:
HRT to induce puberty
Primary amenorrhea with XO karyotype indicates Turner syndrome which needs treatment with HRT.
Gonadectomy is required only if there is an associated Y chromosome as such patients have high risk of gonadoblastoma.

Treatment of Turner syndrome
• The best way to treat this disorder is:
   Hormone replacement therapy
• Hormone replacement therapy is usually started at the time of normal puberty, around 12 years.
• Teenagers are treated with growth hormone to help them reach a normal height.
• They may also be given low doses of androgens (male hormones that females also produce in small quantities) to increase height and encourage hair and muscle growth.
• Some patients may take the female hormone estrogen to promote sexual development.


Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 3003, 3004.

questions.text: A three-year-old child is considered to have a delayed milestone if he does not:

Other options

questions.text: A four-year-old boy was admitted to the hospital with kinky hair and growth retardation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Menke's disease is the most likely cause of a 4-year-old child's kinky hair and growth retardation.

Menkes kinky hair syndrome is an X-linked metabolic disorder of copper metabolism characterized by hypocupremia, mental impairment, and reduced circulating ceruloplasmin. The copper-transporting ATP7A gene is mutated, which results in this condition. Due to dissecting aneurysms or heart rupture, children with this condition frequently pass away within a few years.

questions.text: The following is the preferred treatment option for a 4-day-old baby with bilirubin of 8 mg/dL:
questions.solution:
• The recommended course of treatment for a newborn who is 4 days old and has bilirubin of 8 mg/dL is to continue breastfeeding and receive phototherapy.
  • In contrast to breast feeding jaundice, breast milk jaundice is a distinct condition that results in chronically high indirect bilirubin levels in flourishing, healthy infants.
  • Breast feeding must be done as breast milk is essential for nutrition of the fetus and it doesn't aggravate the condition. 
  • These levels often start to fall in the second to third week of life. Infants with severe or persistent jaundice should be examined for issues such hemolysis, hypothyroidism, galactosemia, and a urinary tract infection.





Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 169-172

questions.text: What does APGAR stand for?
questions.solution:
Apgar score assesses appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration.

APGAR score:
• Helpful clinical tool for determining which newborns need resuscitation and evaluating the success of any such efforts.
• Useful technique for quickly and thoroughly evaluating newborn newborns.
• Fetal distress, premature birth, and medicines given to the mother during labour may all contribute to a poor score.
• 1-minute Apgar score: Indicates that emergency resuscitation is required.
• The 5-minute score, in particular the difference between the 1- and 5-minute scores, is a useful indicator of the success of resuscitative measures.
• The 5-minute Apgar score also has predictive importance for newborn survival since neonatal status in the delivery room is directly associated with survival.





Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 127

questions.text:
After moderate exertion, a 10-year-old kid develops hypoglycemia quickly.
A blood test reveals elevated amounts of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. The liver and kidneys were found to be enlarged during the assessment.The histopathology of the liver reveals excessive glycogen accumulation.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Von-Gierke's disease is strongly suggested by a history of hypoglycemia following moderate exertion, elevated levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides on blood testing, enlarged liver and kidneys, and excess glycogen deposits in the liver.
  • Von Gierke's disease is a glycogen storage disorder which occurs due to deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase.
  • Glycogen is normally broken down into glucose to give you more energy when you need it. This process is impaired in this disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Sprengel’s shoulder?
questions.solution:
Sprengel syndrome is not associated with dextrocardia.
Sprengel syndrome is associated with:
 
  • Klippel-Feil syndrome
  • Kidney disease
  • Scoliosis
  • Diastematomyelia
Sprengel's deformity: The only symptom is deformity, which may be seen at birth.
  • The scapula on the affected side feels excessively high, looks smaller than usual, and is occasionally bothered.
  • The shoulder on the affected side is also raised. The upper thoracic spine may be kyphotic or scoliotic, and the neck appears shorter than typical.
  • Cavendish classification of Sprengel deformity

Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no 489,490

questions.text: What conditions does glucosamine treat?
questions.solution:
Glucosamine is primarily used for pain associated with knee osteoarthritis.

Glycosaminoglycans and other proteoglycans are made in articular cartilage using endogenous glucosamine. In osteoarthritis, the rate of cartilage deterioration outpaces the rate of new cartilage formation. The availability of the essential glycosaminoglycan building blocks is expected to increase with glucosamine supplementation, improving cartilage maintenance and strengthening.

questions.text: A patient complained of lower limb weakness. The examiner lays one hand beneath the patient's heel and instructs the patient to elevate his other leg against downward resistance. What is the name of this examination?
questions.solution:
• In the Hoover test, the subject lies back on the table in a relaxed position while the examiner presses both of the person's heels into his or her palms.
  • Inability to lift a leg may reflect neuromuscular weakness, in hoover’s test.
 
  •

questions.text:
A 40-year-old bodybuilder on steroids and creatinine complained of bilateral hip pain and inability to squat.
There is marrow edoema, a subchondral cyst, flattening of the weight-bearing portions of the femoral head on MRI, and a crescent sign on X-ray.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above history is highly suggestive of avascular necrosis (Osteonecrosis) of femur.

Clinical characteristics:
  • Post-traumatic osteonecrosis appears shortly after a hip injury, though symptoms and signs may take months to manifest.
  • Non traumatic osteonecrosis is more sneaky. Children are impacted by illnesses such Gaucher's disease, sickle cell disease, and Perthes disease.
  • Hip pain is the primary complaint, which becomes worse over the course of two to three years and eventually becomes extremely severe.
  • Below is image of Crescent sign in AVN

    


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 50,51

questions.text:
Analgesic is administered to an adult wearing a POP cast for a forearm fracture.
What is the earliest way for a nurse to recognise the development of compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by the nurse is decreased response to analgesics.
  • When a patient experiences compartment syndrome, the affected area may become increasingly painful, and the pain may not respond to analgesics as expected.
  • This is because the pressure within the muscle compartment can compress nerves and blood vessels, leading to reduced blood flow and tissue damage.
  • Therefore, a decreased response to analgesic is a sign that the patient may be developing compartment syndrome and requires immediate medical attention.
  • Management- Fasciotomy 

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 47

questions.text: What kind of fracture is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
• In the given X-ray of proximal humerus fracture, there is a three-part fracture, which fits it into Neer's type III.
  • It is based on the location and number of fracture fragments
  • Neer Classification for Proximal humerus fractures is as follows
Type I • Minimally Displaced, one-part fracture, fracture lines involve 1-4 parts
Account for ~70-80% of all proximal humeral fractures

Type II • Two-part fracture, fracture lines involve 2-4 parts, one part is displaced (Anatomical neck)

Type III • Three-part fracture, fracture lines involve 3-4 parts, two parts are displaced (Surgical neck)

Type IV • Four-part fracture, fracture lines involve more than 4 parts & three parts are displaced (Greater tuberosity)

Type V • Lesser tuberosity fractures

Type VI • Fracture dislocations






Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 92

questions.text:
A 40 years old male fell on the outstretched hand with radial side pain and
tenderness in anatomical snuffbox and restriction of wrist movement.
Following is the X-ray image. Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
•  X-ray that shows a transverse line in the scaphoid bone and a history of falling on an outstretched hard with radial side discomfort, soreness, and restriction of wrist movement is suggestive of a scaphoid fracture.
  • The scaphoid bone is located in the anatomical snuffbox and is commonly fractured when a person falls on an outstretched hand with radial deviation.
  • Clinical features- Tenderness at the anatomical snuff box.
  • Treatment- Cast in glass holding position

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 115

questions.text:
A patient with a history of RTA arrives at the emergency department.
The attending orthopaedic surgeon writes a IIIB for his both lower limb damage fractures.
Which of the following is the accurate Gustilo-Anderson classification?
questions.solution:
• The Gustilo-Anderson classification is used to classify open fractures where the bone is exposed to the outside environment due to a break in the skin.
  • The classification is based on the severity of the soft tissue injury, which is a major determinant of the prognosis and treatment of the fracture.
 
Type Characteristics
I Puncture wound < 1 cm
Minimal contamination
Minimal soft tissue damage
II Laceration > 1 cm but < 10 cm
Moderate soft tissue damage
Adequate bone coverage
Minimal comminution
III A Laceration > 10 cm
Extensive soft tissue damage
Adequate bone coverage
Segmental/severely comminuted fractures or heavily contaminated wounds
III B As a Gustilo type III A injury, but with periosteal stripping and bone exposure
III C Any open fracture with vascular injury requiring repair
  

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 21

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning the posterior cruciate ligament is false?
questions.solution:
• When the knee is under varus (stress directed towards the midline), the lateral collateral ligament (LCL), not the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL), prevents internal rotation of the tibia on the femur.
  • The PCL stops the femur from pressing anteriorly against the tibia.
  • The PCL avoids the tibia from being dragged posteriorly when the knee joint is flexed.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 149, 145

questions.text: Identify the refractive error shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
In the given image, incident parallel rays come to a focus anterior to the light-sensitive layer of the retina, seen in myopia.

This phenomena occurs due to either increase in the power of the lens or due to lengthening of the eyeball.
Hence, the image is formed in front of the retina.
The defect is corrected by using a Concave lens.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 31, 32.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve palsy is shown in the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. VI nerve palsy

The image shows left eye in adduction, so there is an Abduction constraint which is seen on the left eye of the patient. The abducens nerve, which supplies the lateral rectus muscle, is the cause of lateral gaze palsy. 

Nerve supply of EOM: [MNEMONIC: LR6, SO4, Rest 3]
  • All extraocular muscles are supplied by oculomotor nerve except:
  • Lateral Rectus : Abducens Nerve
  • Superior Oblique : Trochlear Nerve.

questions.text: What is the most common epithelial lacrimal gland tumour?
questions.solution:
These neoplasms are generally classified into two types: epithelial and non epithelial. Non epithelial lesions are the most common, corresponding to 70-80% of solid lacrimal gland masses.
After these, lacrimal gland lymphomas are the most common, accounting for almost 37% of malignant lacrimal gland tumors .
Of the epithelial lacrimal gland tumors, 55% are benign while 45% are malignant.

The most common benign epithelial lesion in the lacrimal gland is the pleomorphic adenoma (PA, also called benign mixed tumor).

Of the malignant epithelial lesions, adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) comprises approximately 60%, with pleomorphic adenocarcinomas, primary adenocarcinomas, mucoepidermoid carcinomas, and miscellaneous tumors making up the remaining 40%.



Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 424.

questions.text:
A patient with glaucoma and a bulging cornea was seen in the eye OPD.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: In cases with anterior staphyloma, there is a bulging of the cornea along with glaucoma (increased IOP). Because the cornea is thin in keratoconus and keratomalacia, the intraocular pressure is lower.

questions.text: A diabetic man in his 60s who had previously experienced reading vision problem presented to the ophthalmology OPD for evaluation. What does the fluorescein angiogram reveal?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
 

  • Neovascularization: The hallmark feature of PDR is the growth of new, abnormal blood vessels (neovascularization), which occur in response to retinal ischemia (lack of oxygen). These vessels typically form on the optic disc (disc neovascularization) and along the retinal periphery.

  • Vitreous Hemorrhage: The newly formed blood vessels are fragile and prone to rupture, leading to bleeding into the vitreous cavity. This can cause sudden vision loss and the appearance of floaters in the visual field.

  • Retinal Detachment: The abnormal blood vessels can contract, causing the retina to detach from its underlying layers. This can lead to severe vision loss and is a common complication in PDR.

  • Fibrous Tissue Formation: In addition to blood vessels, fibrous tissue can form as a result of the neovascularization. This fibrous tissue can cause traction on the retina, further contributing to retinal detachment and other complications.

  • Macular Edema: Although more common in non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), macular edema can also occur in PDR. This involves the accumulation of fluid in the macula, leading to blurred central vision.




Severity classification of DR:

Stage 1: Mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.
  • Microaneurysm plus hard exudate
Stage 2: Moderate nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.
  • Stage 1 + IRMA
Stage 3: Severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.
  • Retinal hemorrhage in 4 quadrants
  • Venous bleeding in 2 quadrants
Stage 4: Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • Neovascularization

FA image of PDR showing Neovascularisation: 



Labelled FA image of various findings seen in Diabetic Retinopathy:


 
Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 545.

questions.text:
Five days after having cataract surgery, a patient with the clinical picture below presented to the eye OPD.
The management of this ailment should include everything except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and images point to a diagnosis of Post-operative endophthalmitis, a dreaded complication of cataract surgery. Antibiotics administered intravenously have no/minimal role in the treatment of endophthalmitis.
  • The preferred method of treatment involves injecting intravitreal antibiotics after removing 0.2–0.3 ml of vitreous tissue to prepare smears and collect cultures.
  • Intravitreal vancomycin provides broad coverage for over 99% of Gram-positive organisms, and ceftazadime is effective against 100% of Gram-negative bacteria observed in post-operative endophthalmitis.
  • Patients presenting with visual acuity at the level of light perception (PL +ve) compared with intravitreal antibiotics alone, pars plana vitrectomy with injection of intravitreal antibiotics appeared to improve the visual outcomes.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 727, 728.

questions.text: Identify the condition show in the image given below
questions.solution:
A pterygium, or wing-shaped protrusion of conjunctiva over the cornea, is visible in the illustration.
  • Pterygium is a growth of fibrovascular tissue on the cornea and conjunctiva. It occurs in the palpebral fissure, much more often nasally than temporally, although either or both (“double” pterygium) occur.
  • Elevated whitish opacities (“islets of Vogt”) and an iron deposition line (“Stocker’s line”) may delineate the head of the pterygium on the cornea.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 206, 207.

questions.text: What is the most commonly affected by noise-induced hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Noise induced hearing loss mostly affects the outer hair cells.

It is of two types:

  • Temporary threshold shift : Hearing status is recovered after a while
  • Permanent threshold shift : Permanent loss of hearing, due to increase in threshold.


Chronic noise exposure damages the metabolism and the ultrastructure of the organ of Corti, initially resulting in the loss of outer hair cells and ultimately leading to neuronal degeneration.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 37

questions.text: Target sign is seen in which of the following cases?
questions.solution:
Target sign is seen in traumatic CSF rhinorrhea.

In cases of traumatic CSF rhinorrhea there is damage to the cribriform plate of the fovea ethmoidalis. 
This trauma causes leakage of both CSF and blood, hence on blotting the discharge, two rings are seen of blood and CSF respectively.

In cases of increased ICP, only CSF discharge occurs, hence target sign is not seen.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 184

questions.solution:
Hutchinson's triad consists of interstitial keratitis + Eighth nerve deafness + Hutchinson incisor.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man came in with itchiness on his fingertips.
Below is a clinical description of the lesion and its etiological agent. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The history of itching across the fingers and the presence of lesions in the finger webs as seen in the picture strongly suggest scabies.
  • Scabies is characterized by intractable itchiness, which is typically worse at night.
  • The lesions first develop on the web gaps, then spread to the sides of the fingers, the flexor surfaces of the wrists and elbows, and the anterior axillary folds.
  • The areolae in women, the buttocks, the sacrum and periumbilical regions, as well as the penis and scrotum, are other common locations for lesions.
  • Eczematous and frequently excoriated lesions are possible, but the burrow—a brief, wavy, dark line—is the hallmark lesion.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 34.41, 34.40

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with the following lesion.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Basal cell carcinoma is strongly suggested by a lesion  with raised, pearly borders, a central crust, and telangiectasia on the lesion's surface.
  • Typically, basal cell carcinomas appear as pearly papules with dilated, noticeable subepidermal blood vessels (telangiectasias). Some cancers have melanin and resemble melanocytic nevi or melanomas on the surface.
  • After years of neglect or in extremely aggressive tumours, advanced lesions may ulcerate and cause considerable local invasion of the bone or face sinuses, which explains the outdated name "rodent ulcers."


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 141.9, 141.10

questions.text: What conditions are related to these two images?
questions.solution:
The lower leg's anterior and lateral surfaces were found to have an inflammatory, indurated plaque with a deep pink or purple color and a "orange skin" appearance.

This may point to the presence of pretibial myxedema, a condition that is seen in patients with Grave's disease (hyperthyroidism).
 
  • In 5% of Graves' disease patients, thyroid dermopathy develops, nearly invariably alongside moderate or severe ophthalmopathy.
 
  • Skin alterations can occur at other areas as well, especially following trauma, despite the fact that they are most common over the anterior and lateral portions of the lower leg (hence the term pretibial myxedema).
 
  • The typical lesion is an indurated, non-inflamed plaque with a "orange skin" look and a deep pink or purple tint. The illness can occasionally spread across the entire lower leg and foot, imitating elephantiasis, and nodules may become involved.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2939.

questions.text: Which of the following results in the following skin changes?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Diabetes mellitus

The presented lesions are indurated, annular, yellowish brown plaques on the shin that are very suggestive of necrosis lipoidica diabeticorum.
 
  • They have an atrophic center and ectatic blood vessels that are visible through the thinner skin (seen in diabetes mellitus).
  • Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is a rare disorder that primarily affects young women with diabetes.
  • This typically starts as an erythematous plaque or papule in the pretibial region and progresses to larger, darker lesions with uneven edges, atrophic cores, and central ulceration. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3128.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female with a history of fever, joint discomfort, and rash visited the OPD. NSAIDs had been recommended.
After a week, the patient's nose started to look reddish. This was caused by?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Chikungunya

After using NSAIDs for one week, the patient developed a reddish discoloration across their nose, as shown in the image. It is known as Chik sign.
  • The mucocutaneous junction (lip, glans) is the most frequently affected region for fixed drug eruption, followed by the vaginal skin (glans). (Option 4)
  • Based on their medical history, which included chronic joint pain and rash, the most likely diagnosis was pigmentation brought on by Chikungunya. 
  • In cases of Chikungunya, the nose pigmentation is noticeable; this condition has not been noted in cases of any other viral exanthem.


Reference: Fitzpatrick's Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 1369.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The given picture is of hand-foot-mouth disease caused by Coxsackie virus.
  • Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease (HFMD): After an incubation period of 4-6 days, patients with HFMD present with fever, anorexia, and malaise; these manifestations are followed by the development of sore throat and vesicles on the buccal mucosa and frequently on the tongue; these lesions are then followed by the appearance of tender vesicular lesions on the dorsum of the hands, occasionally involving the palms.
  • The vesicles may become bullae and ulcerate very soon.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 117.6,117.7

questions.text: Which type of nerve fiber is the most prone to local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Type C fibers are most prone to Local Anesthetics.

questions.text: Which of the following delivers oxygen at its maximum concentration?
questions.solution:
Among the given options Face mask with reservoir delivers close to 90% oxygen concentration.





Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 2595.

questions.text: How long should the patient be pre-oxygenated before being intubated?
questions.solution:
• The recommended duration of preoxygenation before intubation is 3 minutes of deep breathing.
  • The process involves tidal volume ventilation through the face mask for 3 minutes, which allows the exchange of 95% of the gas in the lungs.
  • Transnasal humidified rapid-insufflation ventilatory exchange (THRIVE) at 60 L/min for 3 minutes has been demonstrated to be as effective as tidal volume preoxygenation by face mask.
  • Between the induction of anesthesia and achieving airway security, hypoxemia is possible and is more likely to happen if airway control is challenging.
  • Preoxygenation, also known as denitrogenation, is a technique that can be used to enhance these stores. It involves having the patient breathe 100% oxygen through a tight-fitting facemask prior to the onset of anesthesia. This process provides an increased length of time before hemoglobin desaturation occurs in an apneic patient, known as Apnea time
  • This lengthened apnea time provides an improved margin of safety while the anesthesiologist secures the airway and resumes ventilation

Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1380.

questions.text: For how much time should tracheal secretions be suctioned?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. 10–15 seconds 
  • Tracheal secretions should only be suctioned for 10 to 15 seconds at most.
  • The patient should be preoxygenated for at least a minute with 100% oxygen, and the total suction time should not exceed 10-15 seconds for each attempt.
  • Prolonged suctioning can lead to hypoxia and trauma to the tracheal mucosa.


Reference: 
Pasrija D, Hall CA. Airway Suctioning. [Updated 2023 Feb 15]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557386/

questions.text: Which medication from the list below qualifies as an intravenous induction agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Lorazepam
 
  • Lorazepam can be used as an intravenous induction agent.
  • Lorazepam's effectiveness for preoperative medicine or anesthetic induction is by its delayed start and protracted duration of action, particularly when a quick and sustained waking is desired after surgery.
* Other options: -
  • 1. Bupivacaine- local anesthetic
  • 3. Neostigmine- Acetylcholine esterase inhibitors used in reversal of action of non-depolarizing muscle relaxant
  • 4. Dexmedetomidine- alpha 2 agonist helps as anxiolytic and sedation, used as pre-anesthetic medication.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 428.

Start bag and mask ventilation and reintubate

questions.text: A patient who had been on a ventilator for a few days rips out the endotracheal tube all of a sudden. What comes next in management?
questions.solution:
• In self-extubation, assess the patient, give bag and mask ventilation and look for spontaneous breathing.
  • Self-extubation is the deliberate removal of the endotracheal tube by the patient (Most common  form of unplanned extubation, usually occurs at night).
  • Accidental extubation is usually the result of staff improperly manipulating the tube while providing patient care or a non-intentional patient activity, such as coughing (mostly occur in the morning).

Reference: Handbook of Critical and Intensive Care Medicine by Joseph Varon, 4th edition, page no 61-63, 579.
Saeed F, Lasrado S. Extubation. [Updated 2023 Feb 9]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539804/

questions.text: What does a chest X-ray reveal?
questions.solution:
A right-sided pneumothorax is suggested by the chest X- ray enhanced lucency on the right side, collapse of the right lung, and mediastinal shift to the left.

Most common cause of pneumothorax is spontaneous pneumothorax due to rupture of congenital pleural bleb. 

An expiratory chest X-Ray is the initial investigation modality to be ordered. The radiographic findings are summarized below- 


CT is considered as the gold standard in the diagnosis of pneumothorax. Best diagnosed on lung window images in non-dependent parts. 

Role of Ultrasound- 
The normal lung interface with pleura shows lung sliding with vertical comet tails running down from the pleural surface.



The various USG findings in pneumothorax are enlisted below-




Visceral pleural line sign is positive. 



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 50-52.

questions.text: FDG-PET scans show reduced uptake in:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Typical Carcinoid.
 
  • Due to Warburg effect, FDG selectively localizes to neoplastic cells and helps to detect them. 
  • However, tumors which have less mitotic activity and those who measure < 1 cm in size show decreased uptake on PET and constitute a false negative result. 
The examples include- 
  • Bronchoalveolar carcinoma
  • Lesions < 1 cm in size
  • Lung metastasis from mucinous extrapulmonary tumor
  • Tumor response after chemotherapy
  • Typical carcinoid
Reduced uptake in FDG-PET scan is seen in Typical carcinoids.

The Standardized Uptake Value is used to examine the tumor's 18F-FDG uptake (SUV). Compared to other malignant tumours in the lung, typical carcinoids and bronchoalveolar carcinoma are less FDG avid.


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 6th edition, Page no 352.

questions.text: What does the patient with a history of headaches' digital subtraction angiography reveal?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Aneurysm

The given digital subtraction angiogram shows contrast filled outpouching arising from internal carotid artery which is diagnostic of an aneurysm. 
 
  • Saccular cerebral/berry aneurysms account for most intracranial aneurysms and are the most common cause of non-traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage.
  • Usually arise at arterial bifurcations.
  • Composed of thickened hyalinized intima and muscular wall with internal elastic lamina being absent as the normal muscularis and elastic lamina terminate at the neck of an aneurysm.
  • Tendency to rupture at the dome. 
  • Around 90% of aneurysms arise from the anterior circulation 
    • ACA/Anterior Communicating Artery complex
    • Supraclinoid ICA and ICA/Posterior Communicating Artery junction
    • MCA (M1/M2 junction) bi/trifurcation 
  • Remaining ~ 10% aneurysms arise from the posterior circulation
    • Basilar tip
    • Superior Cerebellar Artery 
    • Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery 
  • Digital subtraction angiography is the gold standard investigation as it is diagnostic as well as therapeutic in case of aneurysms. 
  • Endovascular coiling of the aneurysm is one of the therapeutic options performed under DSA guidance. 
The right internal carotid artery's digital subtraction angiography image displays a balloon-like outpouching that may be an aneurysm.

An aneurysm is a focal enlargement of the vessel wall that most frequently manifests as a balloon-like outpouching but can also be fusiform.
Aneurysms typically develop at the origin of smaller vessels or at the sites where big vessels branch off, such as the internal carotid artery bifurcation.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1382.
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1890.

questions.text: A young male patient who has been taking haloperidol 5 mg for some days has suddenly experienced inner restlessness and a need to move. What is the most likely  Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Akathisia
 
  • Following the use of antipsychotics like haloperidol, inward restlessness and the desire to move are strongly predictive of akathisia.
  • Akathisia is characterized by subjectively felt restlessness, externally seen indicators of restlessness or both. Examples include feeling anxious, having trouble relaxing, being jittery, pacing, rocking back and forth when seated, and frequently standing and sitting.
  • It typically tends to develop 5-50 days post antipsychotic initiation and management includes using drugs like Propranolol/Benzodiazepines.




Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 780.

questions.text: A patient feels that he is the most significant person in the world, and because of their jealousy, his family, neighbors, and even strangers are always watching him giving him secret looks, and then trying to hurt him. He believes the news on TV about certain politicians is about him. His wife says otherwise and claims that he only recently began acting in this manner before being brought to OPD and he was/is working as a teacher. What is he most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given description suggests that the patient is having delusions of grandiosity, persecution, and reference.
 
  • Delusion of grandeur: An exaggerated perception of one's significance, power, or identity is referred to as a delusion of grandeur. (Most significant person in the world)
  • Delusion of persecution: The erroneous belief that one is being harassed or persecuted; frequently observed in litigious patients who have a pathological propensity to file lawsuits over fictitious abuse. (trying to hurt him)
  • Delusion of reference: The false assumption that someone else's behavior is a reflection of their own, or that things, events, or other people have a unique or exceptional significance that is typically negative. (TV news about him)


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 3637.

questions.text: A young patient was admitted to hospital with acute psychosis. He wakes up and asks the nurse to call his wife who was there in the same room in the same area. Upon seeing her, he started beating her thinking that it was nurse who was masquerading as his wife. He also said she was the same nurse who gave her wrong medication 2 days back as well to make him ill, because she wanted to harm him but who was actually his wife. What syndrome he is suffering from?
questions.solution:
• The patient has Capgras syndrome, in accordance with the description provided (the wife, a fa,iliar person has been substituted with the nurse, an impostor).
  • The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the conviction that an impostor has taken the place of a familiar individual
 
  • In Frégoli’s syndrome, a person believes that a familiar person (such as a spouse or loved one) is being impersonated by others, often as part of a delusion that someone is taking on multiple appearances to deceive or harm them.
.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 319, 321.

Digit span backward upto 2 digits with 2 skips allowed

questions.text: Which of the following is the test concentration?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option 1: Serial (100-7) subtraction test up to 5 steps.

This is because the Serial (100-7) subtraction test requires sustained attention, mental focus, and concentration. The task involves repeatedly subtracting 7 from 100, which demands the ability to stay focused over multiple steps, making it a test specifically designed to assess concentration.

Here's why the other options aren't focused on concentration in the same way:

  • Option 2 (Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed): This is a test of short-term memory, specifically how many digits a person can remember in the same order.
  • Option 3 (Digit span backward up to 2 digits with 2 skips allowed): This is a test of working memory, as it requires the individual to not only hold the digits in memory but also to manipulate them by reversing the order.

Since both of the digit span tasks primarily assess memory capacity rather than concentration, Option 1 is the best choice for testing concentration.




Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 203.
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 205

questions.text:
After starting their new job, an IT professional feels guilty, helpless, and unable to focus. His symptoms began three years ago, when he first enrolled in college.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis for the IT professional is Dysthymia, which is a type of chronic depression that lasts for at least two years.
  • The symptoms of Dysthymia are similar to those of major depression, but they are less severe and often go unnoticed. The individual may feel guilty, helpless, and unable to focus, which can affect their ability to function at work and in their personal life.
  • Dysthymia is highly indicative when a melancholy mood lasts for the majority of the day and is usually always present together with accompanying emotions of inadequacy, guilt, impatience, and anger; withdrawal from society; loss of interest; and inactivity and lack of production.
  • Adjustment disorder  is a type of stress-related disorder that occurs when an individual has difficulty coping with a stressful life event, such as starting a new job. However, the duration of symptoms in adjustment disorder is typically less than six months, which is not consistent with the three-year duration of symptoms in this case.
  • Cyclothymic disorder  is a type of mood disorder that involves cycling between periods of hypomania and mild depression. However, the symptoms described in this case are not consistent with cyclothymic disorder, as there is no mention of hypomanic episodes.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 363, 365.

questions.text: Which of the factors does not determine whether patient information provided by informants is reliable?
questions.solution:
A biological relationship need not be present for a good history to exist; for example, the caretaker can provide information on a patient who is staying in a rehabilitation facility for an extended period of time rather than a biological relative.

Reliability of information includes the following criteria:
 
  • Corroborative : Information corroborative with findings of the clinician
  • Consistency : Repeatability of the information by the informant
  • Continuity : Ability to convey the gradual evolution of symptoms ofthe patient over the years.
